reviews.review_msg: Great professor to have for any sociology course. Would definitely take him again in the future if possible. However, he encourages participation from all students since it also counts for marks in the course. I would've gotten an A- if I talked more...
Horrible teacher. Disorganized, doesn't explain new or difficult concepts well. Makes an already dry subject outright painful.

Kathleen was a great prof! She tries to tie boring sociology theories into applicable situations in our modern day society. Make sure you email her or go to her office hours to get a better understanding of what she wants out of her assignments. Exams were fair - she even gave out a study guide! As long as you go to classes, you're set!

Her lectures are interesting, but not much text. She loves to do discussions, so the only note taking chance is there. But she did change up her way of teaching at the end when she put up powerpoints of the main points, I liked that just so I know what I should be noting for. There is a refletion which you have to do weekly.
This class is tough, but the professor keeps it engaging. Lean on resources like the reading and unstuck study to ace the exams. It's a rewarding course if you put in the work.

Probably the best professor I've ever had at SFU. Travers is a very effective prof, keeps classes super engaging, and is incredibly considerate of student wellbeing. This is a really tough class, with a lot of readings and difficult exams, but they make sure you have all the resources and support you need, and overall I HIGHLY recommend

Travers is such a bad prof. Their grading criteria is unclear and exams are so beyond hard. They ask us to find the page of quotes from 500 page book on exams. The lectures are very boring and not engaging at all. Marking is very unfair. Everything is set up for you to fail. I do not recommend taking a class with this prof, stay away at all costs!
tough grader and the comments for the paper are very confusing and bad too. Just don't take classes with them, just don't

Probably the best choice for 350. Really helps you understand the readings in depth, connects theory to historical and contemporary issues. Clear criteria for the paper. Make sure you do all the readings for the exams, they are bareable if you study. If you don't love in class group work might not be the best format for you, but I survived.

Ann is  a seasoned prof with clear expectations of her students, and a good idea of average ability. Her classes aren't for the lazy. Come to class ready for discussion with notes prepared from the readings, and you should have no problem. Ask questions if you're unclear. Participation isn't graded, but it matters!!

Ann makes you want to come to class become of how engaging it is. This class in particular was heavy on readings, but it is a theory course. Assignment and exams were fair and she prepares you well for them

Puts an assignment which requires first 2 months worth of reading, makes the due date 2 days after we are finished with the required readings. Doesn't let us use any electronics (laptop) No txtbook required, but wants us 2 spend money to print the readings out (ink cartridges r expensive) dont bother asking her to repeat what she said. She won't
Keep up with the readings

Ann is a very knowledgeable professor. Her lectures were very relevant to the discussion. During one break she visited with each of the remaining students in the room to see how they were coping with the material. I dislike it when profs go to great lengths to appease their students and having us develop our own class code was silly
One of my most fav profs.  Very responsive to any requests/suggesstions.

Has great enthusiasm for the subject, but actually doesn't go into much depth with the material - you are forced to do the analysis yourself. Tests are easy, paper is short, group work is frequent but not a big part of the grade. Very democratic - allows students to set rules of classroom conduct. Overall, I just wish there was more course content.
SHES CARES ABOUT U!
This woman knows how to teach! Refreshing, fun, informative and comfortable. Favorite teacher at SFU so far.
she is the best prof I have ever had. She is clear, helpful, funny and she knows what she is talking about. Not only I learned a lot I also enjoyed the  classes. And she realy is fare!!!

Efe is a great professor! I came into this class dreading to learn about theory, but Efe made it engaging and inspiring. Yes, there is a lot of reading, but it is what one should expect going into a theory class. Efe was helpful in reading excerpts with the class to help clarify what Marx, Weber and Durkheim were trying to say. Would recommend!

I love his class. He is funny and very interested in the subject. He really tries to make it as clear as possible and really cares how his students are in class or what they think. I love his movie excerpts he has an amazing taste in that ! Overall, great class for a sociology lover!

He is very passionate and interested in what he teaches. Since this is a seminar class, students are encouraged to speak up. He respects every opinion from the students. Although there are some clarification issues in the first part for the first few assignments, overall, he gave us great feedback for our weekly annotations and assignments.

Made no sense. Lots of readings on classical theorists, yet exams based more on slides. He is organized & nice but like in prev. comment is confusing when he asks for something. Very strict, very old school. DO THE DISCUSSION AND RESPONSE ASSIGNMENTS if you want to increase your chances of passing, otherwise this class is suicide. Good luck.

Never have I felt so much as though I was walking on egg shells than in this class. While he can be nice, Gerardo tends to be quite one sided. I don't recommend that in a theory course. Other than that, his marking is pretty fair; what he requests out of his students is often incredibly vague. I wouldn't take upper level courses with him again.
Fair marker but heavy courseload.  Readings are all good but Otero's interpretations are questionable. He is not Marxist as previous student claims. Nice guy generally but can be rude and dismissive.

10 assignments total: news pres, class pres, 3 written commentarys (3 pages each), 4 journals (3 pages each), written summary (7 pages) all based on 2-3 readings PLUS you must reference a minimum additional 4 for each assignment. You have to participate, talks for 1.5 hrs ONLY rest is useless student presentations. Very kind prof but A LOT of work

Efe is very engaged and enthusiastic about topics- he tries to break down complicated ideas - easy to approach and is open to suggestions and discussion - awesome prof:) lots of material to cover for this class but very informative course. Interesting class :)

Clearly Efe is very interested in the subject matter he is teaching, but he is awful at explaining it.  The lectures are boring, vague and convoluted... sometimes he resorts to picking out random quotes.  Expectations and marking criteria are poorly explained so it is very difficult to get a good mark.  Avoid until he develops some teaching skill.

Agnes is one of the kindest and most understanding professors at SFU. While the midterm was a bit challenging, staying on top of the readings and putting in the effort really pays off. She's a fair grader and provides thoughtful, valuable feedback that actually helps you improve. Honestly, Agnes is easily one of my favourite professors!

I took two 300-level classes from her and enjoyed them both. She not only introduces you to social theories but helps work through them through discussion. SA350 was the most memorable and important class I have taken, and I still refer to the notes I took during her lectures 2 years later.

Agnes was fine. She's passionate about sociological theory and the historical contexts. Tough grader for sure, but reaching out helps. You must participate and show that you're doing the work. I don't understand why university students continue to think there'll be handholding and easy passes; academics might not be for you if that's the case.

Agnes's lectures are dry, disjointed, and made on Microsoft word (yes, we scroll through 30 pages of bolded point-form notes). I'm disappointed with how she managed expectations; the lectures were poorly related to the readings and full of information that she refused to clarify if it would be on the exam. Would not recommend a course with Agnes.
